prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Observing strategy: To minimize overheads, the full 150 sq.arcmin GOODS-S field is covered in 12 contiguous mosaics, each respecting the maximum number of 150 pointings and reaching an overhead fraction of 22% (and 48% when including calibration time). Three of these 12 contiguous mosaics are included in this proposal, each as a separate science goal. We performed a simulation of the survey (see Fig.1) and checked that the relative positions of our sub-mosaics are correct and that the heterogeneities of coverage in the central region are lower than 5%.
Band choice: We compared the number of detections in bands 3, 6 and 7. Low frequencies provide larger field sizes, but the dust emission of galaxies is much weaker. We find that band 6 provides the highest number of detections for the same amount of time (see also Da Cunha et al. 2013, ApJ765, 9). To fine tune the central frequency of the survey, we compared the number of detections at 265 GHz and 220 GHz and finally settled for a band 6 around 265 Ghz. Note that our choice of 1.1mm allows to detect twice less luminous galaxies in the mm than the 1.3mm band used in the Cycle 1 HUDF 4sq.arcmin ultra-deep survey (PI Dunlop) except for sources at z>5. We find that for typical IR SEDs, the 0.03mJy-rms depth in the 4sq.arcmin HUDF survey at 1.3mm converts into an equivalent depth of 0.06mJy-rms at 1.1mm, while we will cover a 25 times larger field.
Requested sensitivity: We request a 0.128 mJy RMS sensitivity.
Imaging requirements: We request the most compact configuration (1.5 arcsec resolution) to avoid the spread of the flux of the galaxies into several resolution elements, that would reduce the sensitivity.
Correlator setup: we request continuum imaging in band 6 with the maximal bandwidth (8 GHz) with the highest possible central frequency.
Data processing: We will carry out the data calibration and imaging well within the proposed 3-month proprietary period using computing resources available to the team including a Xeon 372-core cluster at Kavli IPMU. Wiphu Rujopakarn (Kavli IPMU) will start as a postdoctoral scientist (in collaboration with J. Silverman; PI-EA) in the spring of 2014 and is highly experienced with interferometric data analysis stemming from his lead role in extragalactic radio surveys with the Janksy VLA. The EA component of the proposed GOODS-S ALMA survey includes two members of the EA ARC, Daisuke Iono and Bunyo Hatsukade both who can provide an important interface with the ALMA observatory. The EU component includes a member of the ESA ARC, Matthieu Bethermin, a PhD student (C.Schreiber + a future one) and 3 postdocs who will be actively dedicated to this project (Tao Wang and Xinwen Shu at CEA until 2016, Benjamin Magnelli). Bauer, Messias, and Nagar have extensive experience with interferometric datasets and access to high performance computing. The Chilean team includes four Ph.D. students and two postdocs.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to carry out a wide (150 sq.arcmin) and deep (128 microJy rms) ALMA 1.1mm legacy survey in GOODS-South. The present proposal will map a strip covering 11.3'x3.9' in 13.5 hrs. Three coordinated proposals - NA (M.Dickinson), EA (J.Silverman), CH (N.Nagar) - complete the coverage of the full GOODS-S field. The combined power of ALMA and Herschel will probe the dust (hence also gas) content and SFR, hence SFE (=SFR/Mgas), of galaxies out to z=3.5. It will also open a new window on previously undiscovered dusty star formation out to z~6-8, an era previously studied only with UV emission and untested extinction corrections. With ALMA's exquisite angular resolution and sensitivity, >4-10 times deeper than existing sub-mm surveys, these data will provide the missing link between the obscured and unobscured Universe, allowing the deconfusion of Herschel data and permitting statistical studies of galaxy populations via detections and stacking. Our team brings together astronomers from all four ALMA regions, and extensive experience with the GOODS-S multi-wavelength dataset, especially Herschel, radio JVLA, HST and Chandra.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: This proposal is one of a coordinated set of four proposals, which together map the complete GOODS-South region in ALMA band 6. The four proposals are being submitted to the four ALMA regional partners, with the following principal investigators: D.Elbaz (EU), J.Silverman (EA), N.Nagar (CH), and M.Dickinson (NA). All four proposals have the same text, but each one maps distinct, adjacent sky regions, each covering an independent quarter of the GOODS-S field.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
